## Summary: 2026 Six Nations Championship (Wikipedia Article)

**Disclaimer:** The article appears to be incomplete — Rounds 4 and 5 fixtures/results, the final standings table, and player statistics sections contain no extracted data. The summary below reflects only what was available.

---

### Overview
- The 2026 Men's Six Nations Championship (sponsored as "Guinness Men's Six Nations") runs from **5 February to 14 March 2026**, featuring England, France, Ireland, Italy, Scotland, and Wales.
- It is the **132nd season** of the competition and **27th as Six Nations**.
- **France enter as reigning champions**, having reclaimed the title from Ireland in 2025.
- Notable format change: the competition runs over a **reduced timeframe**, with only one rest week (after Round 3) instead of two.

---

### Results Through Round 3 (as of article extraction)

**Round 1:**
- France defeated Ireland (France claimed the inaugural Solidarity Trophy)
- Italy defeated their opponent (reclaimed the Cuttitta Cup; Italy's first opening-round Six Nations win since 2013)
- England played (Tom Roebuck replaced injured Feyi-Waboso)

**Round 2:**
- Ireland won (Edwin Edogbo debuted; Hollie Davidson became first woman to referee a men's Six Nations match)
- Scotland defeated England (reclaimed the Calcutta Cup)
- France defeated Wales **by a record margin** (most points France have ever scored against Wales, surpassing 51 points from 1998; lowest-ever Six Nations attendance in Cardiff: 57,744)

**Round 3:**
- **Ireland defeated England** away — Ireland's 42 points was their highest away score against England; 21-point winning margin was their biggest away win vs. England. Maro Itoje earned his 100th England cap. Ireland retained the Millennium Trophy.
- Scotland defeated Wales (retained the Doddie Weir Cup; Gabriel Hamer-Webb debuted for Wales)
- France defeated Italy (retained the Giuseppe Garibaldi Trophy; Matthieu Jalibert ruled out, Thomas Ramos earned 50th cap)

---

### Rounds 4 & 5
- **No results were available** in the extracted content. The tournament concludes with **France vs. England on 14 March 2026**.

---

### Key Observations (from available data)
- **Ireland** appear strong through Round 3, with a notable away win over England.
- **France** won Round 1 and Round 3 matches but the Round 2 result vs. Ireland (from Round 1) suggests France beat Ireland early.
- **Scotland** picked up a notable win over England (Calcutta Cup).
- **Italy** won their opening match for the first time since 2013.
- **Wales** appear to be struggling, having lost to both France (heavily) and Scotland.
- Final standings and champion are **not determinable** from the extracted content.
</QuestionSource>


<Summary source="https://www.rugbyworld.com/tournaments/rugby-six-nations/six-nations-winners-106318">
## Summary of Article: Six Nations Championship History and Winners

### Key Facts & Statistics

**Six Nations Era (2000–present) Win Counts:**
- **England:** 7 titles (2000, 2001, 2003\*, 2011, 2016\*, 2017, 2020)
- **France:** 7 titles (2002\*, 2004\*, 2006, 2007, 2010\*, 2022\*, 2025)
- **Ireland:** 6 titles (2009\*, 2014, 2015, 2018\*, 2023\*, 2024)
- **Wales:** 6 titles (2005\*, 2008\*, 2012\*, 2013, 2019\*, 2021)
- **Scotland:** 0 titles
- **Italy:** 0 titles

*(\* = Grand Slam)*

### Reigning Champions
- **France** are the current (2025) champions, claiming their **19th overall title** (across all eras). Their 2025 campaign included a record **30 tries** across the tournament, though a loss to England at Twickenham denied them a Grand Slam.

### Notable Context for 2026
- The article notes **England** as potential 2026 contenders, citing their second-place finish in 2025 and a **100% record in the recent Autumn Nations Series**.
- France and England are **level at 7 Six Nations titles each**, the most of any nation in the modern era.

### Historical Overall Records (All Eras Combined)
- England: 29 outright wins, 10 shared
- Wales: 28 outright wins, 11 shared
- France: 19 outright wins, 8 shared
- Ireland: 16 outright wins, 9 shared
- Scotland: 15 outright wins, 9 shared
- Italy: 0 wins

> **Note:** The article does not provide specific predictions or expert opinions about the 2026 championship beyond the brief mention of England as potential contenders.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship">
## Summary: Six Nations Championship (Wikipedia Overview Article)

### Tournament Structure & History
- The Six Nations evolved from the Home Nations Championship (1883–1909, 1932–39), then Five Nations (1910–31, 1947–99), with Italy joining to form the Six Nations in 2000
- Each of the six teams plays every other team once (15 total matches), with the tournament running from the first weekend in February to the second Saturday in March
- A bonus point system was introduced in 2017

### Historical Performance
- **England and Wales** have each won the championship **39 times total**, but England leads in outright titles (29 vs. Wales' 28)
- **Since 2000 (Six Nations era), only Italy and Scotland have never won the title**
- Italy has finished last 18 times in the Six Nations era and been whitewashed (lost all matches) 12 times
- Only England and Ireland have never finished last in the Six Nations era

### 2026-Specific Notes
- A **new rivalry trophy** (the Solidarity Trophy/Trophée Solidarité) will be introduced in 2026 between **Ireland and France**
- France will play their 2026 home match against Italy at **Stade Pierre-Mauroy in Lille**

### Records
- Most points in one match: England 80 vs. Italy (2001)
- Most tries in a season: France, 30 tries in **2025**

*Note: This article is a general overview of the Six Nations Championship and contains no specific predictions or information about the 2026 championship outcome.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Six_Nations_Championship">
## Summary: 2025 Six Nations Championship

### Overview
The 2025 Men's Six Nations Championship ran from **31 January to 15 March 2025**. Ireland entered as two-time reigning champions seeking an unprecedented third consecutive outright title. **France won the championship**, claiming their 7th Six Nations title, 19th outright title in all formats, and 27th title overall — defeating Scotland in the final match.

### Final Table Context
France topped the standings. The article does not provide the full final table, but France's dominance was clear throughout the tournament.

### Key Team Performances
- **France**: Record-breaking tournament — most tries in a single Six Nations (30), largest ever away win against Ireland, highest points total against Italy
- **Ireland**: Lost to France in a historic defeat (France's biggest ever away win against Ireland); still won 11 consecutive matches vs. Scotland
- **Wales**: Received a second consecutive Wooden Spoon; suffered their heaviest home defeat; Warren Gatland departed as head coach mid-tournament
- **England**: Recorded their highest points total and largest away win against Wales
- **Italy**: Recorded back-to-back victories over Wales for the first time

### Notable Individual Records
- **Louis Bielle-Biarrey (France)**: Player of the Championship; set record for most tries in a single Six Nations tournament (**8 tries**)
- **Thomas Ramos (France)**: Became France's all-time top test points scorer
- **Damian Penaud (France)**: Became France's joint top try scorer in test history (38 tries)
- **Cian Healy (Ireland)**: Became Ireland's most-capped Six Nations player (66 appearances)

### Tournament Records Set in 2025
- Most points scored across a tournament: **829**
- Most tries scored across a tournament: **108**
- Most tries by one player in a tournament: **8** (Bielle-Biarrey)
- Most tries by one team in a tournament: **30** (France)

### Awards
- **Player of the Championship**: Louis Bielle-Biarrey (France)
- **Try of the Championship**: Louis Bielle-Biarrey (vs. Ireland)
- **BKT Rising Player Award**: Sam Prendergast (Ireland)
</Summary>


<Summary source="https://www.statista.com/statistics/1441336/most-grand-slams-won-six-nations-countries-era/?srsltid=AfmBOoo0E-SYX-YXNPUSkYwjZF4lhsa1EV9gGWYH0Sc1EVaFpIRMh267">
## Summary

**Source:** Statista (data sourced from Six Nations Rugby, published November 23, 2023)

**Note:** The article's specific numerical values for Grand Slam counts appear to have been redacted or obscured in the extracted content (shown as \*\*\*\*), limiting the precision of this summary.

### Key Facts:

- **Six Nations era (since Italy joined in 2000):** Wales and France are tied for the most Grand Slams won in this era.
- **Five Nations era (1910–1931 and 1947–1999):** England won the most Grand Slams.
- A **Grand Slam** is defined as beating every other team in the competition — meaning winning all five matches in the Six Nations format.
- **Italy** has never won a Grand Slam and was omitted from the ranking.
- The competition dates back to 1883 (originally the Home International Championship), with France joining in 1910, being excluded in 1931, rejoining in 1947, and Italy entering in 2000.
- Competitions in **1885, 1897, 1898, and 1972** were not completed.

### Relevance to Forecast:
This article provides **historical context** on dominant nations (England historically, Wales and France in the modern Six Nations era) but contains **no forward-looking predictions** about the 2026 championship.
</Summary>

## Summary: Six Nations Championship (Wikipedia Overview Article)

### Tournament Structure & History
- The Six Nations evolved from the Home Nations Championship (1883–1909, 1932–39), then Five Nations (1910–31, 1947–99), with Italy joining in 2000 to form the current Six Nations
- Each of the six teams plays every other team once (15 total matches), with the tournament running from the first weekend in February to the second Saturday in March
- A bonus point system was introduced in 2017

### Historical Performance
- **England and Wales** have each won the championship **39 times total**, but England leads in outright titles (29 vs. Wales' 28)
- **Since 2000 (Six Nations era), only Italy and Scotland have never won the title**
- Italy has finished last 18 times in the Six Nations era and been whitewashed (lost all matches) 12 times

### 2026-Specific Notes
- A **new rivalry trophy** (the Solidarity Trophy/Trophée Solidarité) will be introduced in 2026 between **Ireland and France**
- France will play their 2026 match against Italy at **Stade Pierre-Mauroy in Lille**
- The UK broadcast deal (BBC/ITV) has been extended through 2029

### Records of Note
- England scored the most points in a season (229 in 2001)
- France scored the most tries in a season (30 in **2025**)

*No specific information about the 2026 Six Nations Championship results or predictions is contained in this article.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship">
## Summary: Six Nations Championship (Wikipedia Overview Article)

### Tournament Structure & History
- The Six Nations evolved from the Home Nations Championship (1883–1909, 1932–39), then the Five Nations (1910–31, 1947–99), with Italy joining in 2000 to form the current Six Nations
- Each of the six teams plays every other team once (15 total matches), with home advantage alternating yearly
- The tournament runs from the first weekend in February through the second Saturday in March
- A bonus point system was introduced in 2017

### Historical Performance
- **England and Wales** have each won the championship **39 times total**, but England leads in outright titles (29 vs. Wales' 28)
- **Since 2000 (Six Nations era), only Italy and Scotland have never won the title**
- Italy has finished last 18 times in the Six Nations era and been whitewashed (lost all matches) 12 times
- Only England and Ireland have never finished last in the Six Nations era

### 2026-Specific Notes
- A **new rivalry trophy** (the Solidarity Trophy/Trophée Solidarité) will be introduced in 2026 between **Ireland and France**
- France will play their 2026 home match against Italy at **Stade Pierre-Mauroy in Lille**

### Administration & Broadcasting
- Six Nations Rugby Ltd. is headquartered in Dublin; Tom Harrison became CEO in April 2023
- UK broadcasting rights are shared between BBC and ITV through 2029

*Note: This article is a general overview of the Six Nations Championship and contains no specific predictions, odds, or performance data relevant to the 2026 tournament outcome.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.hospitalityfinder.co.uk/blog/six-nations-rugby-the-rules-explained/">
## Summary: Six Nations Rugby Rules Explained (Hospitality Finder, Oct. 14, 2025)

**Disclaimer:** This article is a general explainer about Six Nations rules and format, written for a hospitality/tourism audience. It contains **no predictive content, team performance analysis, or information specific to the 2026 tournament.** Its relevance to forecasting the 2026 winner is limited to clarifying competition structure.

---

### Key Structural Facts Relevant to Forecasting:

- **Participants:** England, France, Ireland, Italy, Scotland, and Wales
- **Format:** Round-robin; each team plays **5 matches** over ~7 weeks (typically early February to mid-March)
- **Points System:** Win/draw/loss-based accumulation (specific point values not fully detailed in the article)
- **Tiebreakers:** Applied when teams finish level on competition points (specific tiebreaker order mentioned but not fully enumerated in the extracted text)
- **Grand Slam:** Awarded to a team that wins **all five matches** (worth 20 points total — a prestigious achievement)
- **Home/Away:** Teams alternate between **3 home and 2 away** matches annually

### Tournament Traditions Noted:
- **Wooden Spoon** for last-place finisher
- **Calcutta Cup** contested between England and Scotland

*No team rankings, recent results, expert predictions, or 2026-specific information are present in this article.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.bbc.com/sport/rugby-union/articles/c4g9v9yl4jdo">
## Summary: Six Nations Points System Explained (BBC Sport, January 30, 2025)

### Competition Format
- Round-robin format: 6 teams, each playing 5 matches
- Home advantage alternates each season

### Points System
| Result | Points |
|--------|--------|
| Win | 4 points |
| Draw | 2 points |
| Loss | 0 points |

### Bonus Points (introduced in 2017)
- **+1 point** for scoring 4+ tries in a single match
- **+1 point** for losing by 7 or fewer points
- **+3 points** for winning all five matches (Grand Slam bonus)
- Maximum points per game: **5** (win + try bonus)

### Key Structural Notes
- The Grand Slam bonus (3 pts) is designed to **guarantee the Grand Slam winner tops the table** — a Grand Slam winner earns at least 23 points, which cannot be surpassed by a team winning only 4 games
- **Tiebreakers** (in order): points difference → total tries scored

### Notable Historical Examples Referenced
- **2020**: England won title on points difference over France
- **2022**: England finished above Scotland (both 10 pts) on points difference (+5 vs -29)
- **2024**: England's two bonus points in a loss to France proved decisive over Scotland in final standings
</Summary>


<Summary source="https://www.planetrugby.com/news/six-nations-round-three-winners-and-losers-as-gregor-townsend-saves-face-but-for-how-long-while-englands-campaign-in-tatters">
## Summary: Six Nations Round Three – Winners and Losers

**Context:** This article reviews Round 3 of the 2026 Six Nations, after which **Ireland, Scotland, and France** all won and remain in title contention. A rest week follows before the final two rounds.

---

### Key Results Mentioned:
- **Scotland 26–23 Wales** (in Cardiff) – hard-fought Scottish win
- **Ireland beat England** at Twickenham (Allianz Stadium) – described as a "record victory" over England
- **Italy beat France** (in Lille) – Italy's scrum dominance a key factor
- **Wales lost to Scotland** despite claiming 9 turnovers and limiting Scottish errors

---

### Notable Observations:

**Winners:**
- **Gregor Townsend (Scotland coach):** Survives calls for his sacking; Scotland won despite a poor performance. Next match vs. France will be pivotal for his future.
- **Andy Farrell (Ireland coach):** Vindicated by Ireland's emphatic record win over England; his selection choices proved correct.
- **Gibson-Park & Crowley (Ireland):** Both outstanding; Gibson-Park named Man of the Match; Crowley's starting spot still uncertain vs. Prendergast.
- **Stuart McCloskey (Ireland):** Described as Ireland's best player through three rounds.
- **Italy's front row** (Fischetti, Ferrari, Spagnolo): Scrum dominance continues; have now beaten Scotland, Ireland, and France in scrums across recent matches.

**Losers:**
- **Matthieu Jalibert (France):** Lost starting fly-half spot to Thomas Ramos for the Italy match; Ntamack's return threatens his position further.
- **Maro Itoje & England:** England's campaign described as "in tatters"; Itoje's 100th cap occasion was overshadowed by the record defeat to Ireland.

---

### Title Race Standing (implied):
Ireland, Scotland, and France remain in contention after Round 3. Italy's strong performances (beating France in Round 3) make them a disruptive force, though their title prospects are not explicitly discussed.

*Note: The article appears to be cut off near the end, so some content regarding Maro Itoje and England may be incomplete.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.corinthiansports.co.uk/blog/mens-six-nations-2026-round-3-recap">
## Round 3 Recap – 2026 Guinness Men's Six Nations (February 23, 2026)

### Overall Tournament Picture
After Round 3, the article describes the championship as increasingly clarified, with **France leading on maximum points**, **Ireland and Scotland emerging as strong contenders**, and **England, Wales, and Italy** facing varying degrees of difficulty.

---

### Match Results & Key Takeaways

**England 21 – Ireland 42** (at Twickenham)
- Described as one of Ireland's most dominant modern Six Nations performances
- Ireland controlled breakdown, midfield, and tempo throughout; second half was "one-way traffic"
- Standout performers: Jamison Gibson-Park (game management), Stuart McCloskey (midfield), Dan Sheehan (physicality)
- Article characterizes England's loss as exposing "systemic issues," not merely a bad day

**Wales 23 – Scotland 26**
- Wales led for much of the match but Scotland mounted a composed, structured comeback
- Finn Russell credited for territorial kicking and composure under pressure; Darcy Graham noted as a consistent threat
- Scotland described as "genuine contenders"; Wales flagged as being in a "dangerous psychological space"

**France 33 – Italy 8**
- France won through disciplined, structured "control rugby" rather than flair
- Antoine Dupont and Louis Bielle-Biarrey highlighted as standout performers
- France described as operating at "title level consistency"; Italy praised for competitiveness but outclassed

---

### Standings Implication (per article)
- **France**: Top of the table, maximum points, described as "complete, balanced and psychologically strong"
- **Ireland**: Momentum restored after a dominant Twickenham win
- **Scotland**: Positioned as genuine title contenders
- **England, Wales**: Both facing structural/confidence concerns after losses
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://rugbyisthegame.com/2026/02/25/six-things-we-learned-from-round-3-of-the-guinness-six-nations/">
## Summary: Six Things Learned from Round 3 of the 2026 Six Nations

**Tournament Context (after Round 3):**
- Ireland dismantled England 42-21 at Twickenham (Ireland's biggest ever away win over England)
- Scotland beat Wales 26-23 in a comeback from 20-5 down
- France beat Italy 33-8 in Lille (though the scoreline flattered France)

---

### Key Takeaways:

**Ireland** have roared back into title contention after two underwhelming performances. Despite being four points behind France, their dominant Twickenham display — featuring standout performances from Gibson-Park, McCloskey, and Crowley (17 points) — proved they remain capable of beating anyone.

**England** are described as being "in freefall" after back-to-back heavy defeats. Their title hopes are effectively over, with concerns raised about coaching decisions, lineout failures, and a loss of tactical identity. They still face Italy and France.

**Scotland** demonstrated newfound resilience by grinding out an ugly win in Cardiff, keeping their title hopes alive. Their key test remains France at Murrayfield in Round 4.

**France** remain tournament favourites but showed vulnerability against Italy for 70 minutes. Jalibert's pre-match injury forced Ramos to fly-half, and set-piece issues emerged. They lead the table by four points over Ireland.

**Italy** are highlighted as genuine contenders for a top-half finish, having troubled France, beaten Scotland, and narrowly lost to Ireland. Home games against England and Wales still to come make a third win plausible.

**Wales**, despite losing, showed improved fighting spirit — though they remain in the lower half of the table.

---

### Standings Implication:
France lead by four points but face Scotland (away) and England (home) in remaining rounds. Ireland, Scotland, and potentially others remain mathematically in contention.
</Summary>


<Agent_report>
Query: [Agent] Provide dataset of every Six Nations season 2000-2025: identify the team leading the table after Round 3 and the eventual champion; calculate probability that the Round-3 leader wins and list seasons where another team overtook them.
Objective.  The requester wants a 26-row data set (2000-2025 seasons) with (a) the team that topped the Six Nations table after Round 3 and (b) the team that ultimately won the title; then (c) the empirical probability that the Round-3 leader held on to win, plus (d) a list of the seasons in which the title was won by a team that was NOT leading after Round 3.

What we can already fill in.  The eventual champions for every season are well documented.  Rugby World’s historical list (rugbyworld.com – Six Nations winners, 2000-2025) gives:

• 2000 England • 2001 England • 2002 France • 2003 England • 2004 France • 2005 Wales • 2006 France • 2007 France • 2008 Wales • 2009 Ireland • 2010 France • 2011 England • 2012 Wales • 2013 Wales • 2014 Ireland • 2015 Ireland • 2016 England • 2017 England • 2018 Ireland • 2019 Wales • 2020 England • 2021 Wales • 2022 France • 2023 Ireland • 2024 Ireland • 2025 France (Rugby World, source 1).

That supplies column (b).

Information still missing.  None of the supplied search results give a round-by-round standings archive, with the lone exception of a snippet for the 2000 season (“England moved one step closer … after Round 3” – RugbyPass, source 10) which merely implies England were Round-3 leaders that year but does not enumerate the exact table.  No comprehensive source in the results lists who led after Round 3 for the other 25 editions.

Why that matters.  Without those Round-3 leaders we cannot:

• build the requested full dataset,  
• count how many times leader = champion,  
• calculate the requested probability, or  
• list the seasons in which a different team overtook the Round-3 leader.

Remaining gap.  A season-by-season Round-3 standings archive (2000-2025).

Recommended next data source.  The official Six Nations site (sixnationsrugby.com) historically publishes a “table” page after each round; those URLs are often still accessible by adding a query string such as “…/table?round=3&season=YYYY”.  ESPN Scrum also keeps week-by-week standings in its season pages.  Either archive would let us extract the Round-3 leader for all 26 seasons.

Once that table is compiled we can:

1.  Count N = 26 seasons.  
2.  Count k = (seasons where Round-3 leader eventually champion).  
3.  Probability = k / 26.  
4.  Create the list of (26 – k) seasons where the leader was overtaken.

Until we retrieve that round-3 information the requested probability and “overtaken seasons” list cannot be produced.

Conclusion.  The champion column is complete (sources above).  The Round-3-leader column is still missing for 25 of the 26 seasons, so the probability calculation and overtaken-season list cannot yet be generated.  An additional targeted search of official Six Nations or ESPN Scrum round-by-round tables is required to finish the data set.</Agent_report>
